citation.article-title: Rearrangements of the species and genera of the phototrophic "purple nonsulfur bacteria."

p.s: Rhodopila (Rho.do.pi'la. Gr.n. rhodon rose; M. L. fem.n. pila ball or sphere; M. L.fem.n. Rhodopila red-colored spherical bacterium)
The type species of Rhodopila is Rhodopila globiformis Pfennig 1974 comb. nov.
Formerly this species has been included in the genus Rhodopseudomonas.
Cells are spherical to ovoid and motile by means of flagella, have vesicular intracytoplasmic membranes, and grow only at low pH values.
Biotin and p-aminobenzoic acid are required as growth factors.
Cells are sensitive to oxygen, but growth at low oxygen tensions in the dark is possible.

The intracytoplasmic membrane structure is similar to that of Rhodobacter species, but a number of significant differences exist between these two genera. Rhodopila reduces adenosine 5'- phosphosulfate instead of 3'-phosphate adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate, has different quinone, carotenoid, and polar lipid compositions, and has a small cytochrome c2.

It stands apart from Rhodobacter and Rhodopseudomonas species according to DNA-rRNA hybridization studies and 16s rRNA analyses, and it has in common with Rhodomicrobium vannielii reduction of sulfate via adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate, the presence of a small type of cytochrome c2 substantial amounts of a high-potential iron-sulfur protein, and the presence of unusual arninolipids as major components of the polar lipids.
Therefore, Rhodopila is significantly different from all other genera and should be recognized as a separate genus.
